content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <feed xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom"> <title>Open</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/10672/2" rel="alternate"/> <subtitle>ShareGeo Open Default collection</subtitle> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/10672/2</id> <updated>2015-03-06T08:41:21Z</updated> <dc:date>2015-03-06T08:41:21Z</dc:date> <entry> <title>Mean High Water Springs Polygon</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/10672/609" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name/> </author> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/10672/609</id> <updated>2014-11-19T16:43:02Z</updated> <published>2014-11-19T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Mean High Water Springs Polygon Mean high water (springs) polygon. This data was extracted from Ordnance Survey Boundary Line and polygonised using ArcGIS 10.2.  Boundary Line is available as OS OpenData, further information about the dataset can be found at: http://www.ordnancesurvey.co.uk/docs/user-guides/boundary-line-user-guide.pdf </summary> <dc:date>2014-11-19T00:00:00Z</dc:date> </entry> <entry> <title>Broad Rental Market Areas (Scotland)</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/10672/608" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name/> </author> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/10672/608</id> <updated>2014-10-14T13:37:26Z</updated> <published>2014-10-13T23:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Broad Rental Market Areas (Scotland) Broad Rental Market Areas (BRMAs) are the geographical areas used to determine Local Housing Allowance (LHA) rates. This dataset covers Scotland only. Please see the Doc folder for more details. Released by Rent Service Scotland (part of the Scottish Government) on 14/10/2014 via correspondence (enclosed). </summary> <dc:date>2014-10-13T23:00:00Z</dc:date> </entry> <entry> <title>Landcover Classification of Luambe National Park and Surrounding Game Management Areas, Zambia</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/10672/607" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Anderson, Neil</name> </author> <author> <name>Bessell, Paul</name> </author> <author> <name>F\ufffd\ufffdvre, Eric</name> </author> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/10672/607</id> <updated>2014-09-29T14:12:35Z</updated> <published>2014-09-24T23:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Landcover Classification of Luambe National Park and Surrounding Game Management Areas, Zambia Anderson, Neil; Bessell, Paul; F\ufffd\ufffdvre, Eric Luambe National Park (LNP) is a small, remote and relatively undeveloped national park in the Luangwa Valley, eastern Zambia. Baseline ecological data have been lacking and few publications relating to the ecology of the national park and surrounding game management area (GMA) exist. The aim of this work was to produce an accurate landcover classification that could be used as a baseline dataset for monitoring ecological health in the park. Fuzzy set theory was used to classify remotely sensed Landsat 7 ETM+ imagery with a spatial resolution of 30m. A ground survey to collect training and test data was conducted in August and September 2005. The most recent L1G Landsat dataset was obtained from the Global Land Cover Facility maintained by the University of Maryland (acquisition date 04/10/2001, path 170, row 069, cloud cover 0%). Bands one, two, three, four, five and seven were used for the classification. Erdas Imagine 8.4 (Leica Geosystems AG, Atlanta, USA) was used to perform a supervised classification using the maximum likelihood classifier with activation of the fuzzy classification function.  The eight-layered output dataset was then processed to a single-layer hard classification using the fuzzy convolution facility. An error matrix was produced and producer\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds and user\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds accuracies calculated for each class. Nine landcover classes were identified and the overall accuracy of the classification was 71.2% (95% CI: 65.3-76.7%). The overall kappa statistic was 0.67 and the estimator of kappa (KS) for stratified random sampling was 0.74. This is the complete dataset covering both the national park and the surrounding GMA. The dataset for the national park alone can be found using the identifier http://hdl.handle.net/10672/606. Developed as part of Neil Anderson\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds thesis entitled \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdAn Investigation into the Ecology of Trypanosomiasis in the Luangwa Valley, Zambia\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd (PhD thesis, University of Edinburgh 2009). Landsat imagery was processed using Erdas Imagine 8.4 (Leica Geosystems AG, Atlanta, USA). Funding was provided by the Royal Zoological Society of Scotland and the United Kingdom Department for International Development Animal Health Programme (DFID-AHP). </summary> <dc:date>2014-09-24T23:00:00Z</dc:date> </entry> <entry> <title>Landcover Classification of Luambe National Park, Zambia</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/10672/606" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Anderson, Neil</name> </author> <author> <name>Bessell, Paul</name> </author> <author> <name>F\ufffd\ufffdvre, Eric</name> </author> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/10672/606</id> <updated>2014-09-29T14:14:28Z</updated> <published>2014-09-23T23:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Landcover Classification of Luambe National Park, Zambia Anderson, Neil; Bessell, Paul; F\ufffd\ufffdvre, Eric Luambe National Park (LNP) is a small, remote and relatively undeveloped national park in the Luangwa Valley, eastern Zambia. Baseline ecological data have been lacking and few publications relating to the ecology of the national park and surrounding game management area (GMA) exist. The aim of this work was to produce an accurate landcover classification that could be used as a baseline dataset for monitoring ecological health in the park. Fuzzy set theory was used to classify remotely sensed Landsat 7 ETM+ imagery with a spatial resolution of 30m. A ground survey to collect training and test data was conducted in August and September 2005. The most recent L1G Landsat dataset was obtained from the Global Land Cover Facility maintained by the University of Maryland (acquisition date 04/10/2001, path 170, row 069, cloud cover 0%). Bands one, two, three, four, five and seven were used for the classification. Erdas Imagine 8.4 (Leica Geosystems AG, Atlanta, USA) was used to perform a supervised classification using the maximum likelihood classifier with activation of the fuzzy classification function.  The eight-layered output dataset was then processed to a single-layer hard classification using the fuzzy convolution facility. An error matrix was produced and producer\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds and user\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds accuracies calculated for each class. Nine landcover classes were identified and the overall accuracy of the classification was 71.2% (95% CI: 65.3-76.7%). The overall kappa statistic was 0.67 and the estimator of kappa (KS) for stratified random sampling was 0.74. This dataset contains the landcover classification for the national park area only. The dataset for the national park and surrounding game management areas can be found using the identifier http://hdl.handle.net/10672/607. Developed as part of Neil Anderson\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds thesis entitled \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdAn Investigation into the Ecology of Trypanosomiasis in the Luangwa Valley, Zambia\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd (PhD thesis, University of Edinburgh 2009). Landsat imagery was processed using Erdas Imagine 8.4 (Leica Geosystems AG, Atlanta, USA). Funding was provided by the Royal Zoological Society of Scotland and the United Kingdom Department for International Development Animal Health Programme (DFID-AHP). </summary> <dc:date>2014-09-23T23:00:00Z</dc:date> </entry> </feed>
